;;P;;政治不稳定;和宪法不确定性构成了过去八年的英国政治。议会、政府和法院似乎围绕英国脱欧展开了无休无止的斗争。一波关于个别议员行为和政府高层违法行为的丑闻削弱了公众对政治家和政治机构的信任。 2022 年，三任总理的任期损害了该国作为稳定民主国家的声誉。由于北爱尔兰政府持续缺席，而苏格兰政府不断努力争取独立，英国的未来面临着重大问题。宪法的界限已经受到考验，有时甚至超出了其极限。

;

;英国的不同寻常之处在于，没有任何一份可以由法院执行的书面宪法文件。相反，它有一部严重依赖规范和惯例的政治宪法。当挑战出现时，它取决于对规则的共同理解以及主要参与者在很大程度上愿意遵守这些规则——政府的“好人”理论。当行为者越界，甚至考虑这样做时，政治制衡体系就会涉及<小>;议员、上议院议员、部长、公务员、权力下放机构、媒体最终是公众——旨在确保他们要么无法这样做，要么因其行为而受到惩罚。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;然而，在过去的八年里，政客们越来越愿意测试宪法的界限。英国议会在未经苏格兰、威尔士和北爱尔兰各自立法机构同意的情况下通常不会通过有关移交苏格兰、威尔士和北爱尔兰事务的立法的公约——这一公约已经维持了数十年——被搁置为威斯敏斯特政府寻求实施英国脱欧。与<小>;欧盟;在脱欧条款上的争议也导致政府两次提出立法，这些立法如果获得通过，将违反国际法，因为北爱尔兰协议是英国脱欧协议的一部分。实际上，在爱尔兰海划定了边界。鲍里斯·约翰逊试图让议会休会（迫使议会休会）以阻止对其政府脱欧协议的反对，但失败了，这表明他愿意以一种曾经不可想象的方式结束民主辩论。

;

;政客们越来越愿意为了实现具体的政策目标而搁置关键的宪法原则。在大多数国家，宪法是一种高级法律，凌驾于日常政治之上。在英国，两者日益交织在一起，主要政治家寻求以适合他们议程的方式解释宪法。考虑一下苏格兰民族党坚持认为，在<小>;英国;大选中获得苏格兰多数席位将赋予其独立授权，或者约翰逊先生及其盟友声称他在大选中获胜2019 年——他的“个人”任务——使他脱离保守党领导层成为对民主的侮辱。

;

;如此大胆的宪法主张需要密切、权威的审查。不幸的是，英国的体系未能提供独立的挑战来源。我们工作的政府研究所最近;对宪法的审查;，和贝内特公共政策研究所得出的结论是，迫切需要加强对权力的制约，以支撑我们的政治宪法。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这可以通过多种方式实现。一种方法是建立一个强大的跨党派委员会，独立于当时的政府，提供对宪法的权威意见。该机构可以弥补议员可获得的信息和分析的缺乏，增强他们履行宪法维护职责的能力。

;

;此外，影响宪法的立法应该被归为一个单独的类别。目前，在英国，《人权法》等主要宪法立法与《马戏团野生动物法》等次要法律之间几乎没有什么有意义的区别。因此，立法者对修改我们政治制度基础的法案很少给予额外的关心或关注，而这些法案很容易在议会中匆忙通过。创建新类别的宪法法案有助于加强围绕宪法变革的进程，同时也强调了法律对于权力下放等宪法重要性问题的重要性。

;

;还可以采取更多措施来帮助部长们理解并承担他们的职责。与宪法有关的义务。在政府中建立一个新的宪法专业知识中心可以确保他们在最复杂的问题上获得高质量的建议。建立官员可以提出对宪法适当性的担忧的机制，将有助于确保部长们在选择偏离既定宪法实践时承担责任。对管理政治机构的不成文规则进行更清晰的指导，并列出一份简单的高级宪法原则（类似于 20 世纪 90 年代约翰·梅杰政府制定的关于公共生活标准的诺兰原则），可以为判断提供一个共同基础。此类决定。

;

;过去十年凸显了加强英国政治宪法护栏的必要性。如果允许近年来的宪法不稳定继续下去，要求进行更激进改革的呼声将会越来越高。英国宪法经常被描述为进化的产物。它迫切需要再次发展。;■;

;

;;Jess Sargeant 领导政府研究所对;英国; 宪法，并担任智囊团副主任。汉娜·怀特 (Hannah White) 是其主任。;

;;E;;VEN BEFORE; 统治加沙的激进组织哈马斯于 10 月袭击了以色列7日，赫兹·哈勒维中将处境艰难。 2023年1月，当他就任以色列国防军（;IDF;）总参谋长（以色列军队最高职位）时，军官和预备役部队均由;部门;关于对该国;最高法院;。一些预备役军人威胁说，如果分裂的总理本雅明·内塔尼亚胡及其极右翼联盟通过削弱法院权力的法律，他们就不会服役。这是近代军队最动荡的时期之一。

;

;哈马斯谋杀了 1,400 名以色列人，并扣押了 200 多名人质，这一切都黯然失色。哈勒维将军现在正在指挥空中和 ;对以色列的行为方式感到愤怒;战争激起了许多国家的抗议。 ;联合国;人权办公室表示，以色列可能犯下了;战争罪;袭击;贾巴利亚难民营;。内塔尼亚胡政府的一位部长提出了对加沙使用核武器的可能性（他因言论而被停职）。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;但总的来说，哈勒维以色列有一位在维护法律方面享有盛誉的指挥官和战争行为的道德标准。他的背景是什么？这会如何影响他发动战争的方式？他于 1967 年出生于耶路撒冷，以他的叔叔的名字命名，他的叔叔在几个月前的一次行动中阵亡 ;六日战争;。他母亲的家族已经在这座城市生活了14代；他的祖父母从俄罗斯移民。他父亲的父亲是伊尔贡的成员，这是一个犹太复国主义准军事组织，活跃于以色列建国前的几年。

;

;这位将军 18 岁开始在正规军服役，作为一名伞兵，两年后开始接受军官训练。在他职业生涯的早期，他与;真主党;发生了小冲突，黎巴嫩南部的一个什叶派武装组织目前正在与以色列交火，并加入了马特卡尔特种部队，这是一支在阿拉伯国家深处进行秘密行动的特种部队，最终由他指挥。接下来，他在被占领的约旦河西岸领导了一个旅;。 2009年，他在加沙率领伞兵对加沙城以北的城镇发动地面攻势，以色列国防军再次在此交战。

;

;哈勒维将军自 2011 年起担任加利利师指挥官，在黎巴嫩边境领导;以色列国防军;。他于 2014 年成为军事情报部门负责人，并从 2018 年起担任南方司令部负责人，负责威慑哈马斯。

;

;这是在他经历了;之后2008-09 年的加沙战争造成数百名巴勒斯坦平民死亡，这使他成为战争行为合法和道德的直言不讳的倡导者。在2009年的一次演讲中，他批评其他以色列战地指挥官未能为在有许多平民在场的城市地区作战的士兵制定“道德标准”。他说：“士兵不能带着法律书上战场，”但指挥官有责任确保道德和法律标准得到遵守。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;哈莱维将军的观点属于以色列军事传统。以色列国防军前身犹太复国主义民兵组织哈加纳 (Haganah) 的领导人伊扎克·萨德 (Yitzhak Sadeh) 创造了“武器纯洁”一词，并警告武装分子不要肆意报复。但<小>;以色列国防军;也有忽视这些原则的指挥官。 1953 年，阿里尔·沙龙 (Ariel Sharon) 担任年轻突击队军官，2001 年至 2006 年期间担任总理，在当时由约旦控制的约旦河西岸的一个村庄齐比亚（Qibya）发动了报复行动，造成 69 名巴勒斯坦人死亡。三十年后，以色列委员会发现，时任国防部长沙龙没有采取行动阻止以色列盟友对黎巴嫩难民营中的巴勒斯坦人进行屠杀。

;

;哈勒维将军领导;以色列国防军;之际，萨德的道德正受到沙龙复仇精神的挑战。与 2009 年和 2014 年相比，;以色列国防军;已经深入加沙城，哈马斯已经做好了更充分的准备;防御工事;和隧道。随着平民伤亡不断增加、激烈的轰炸和近距离战斗的进行，道德和法律战争的概念正在受到考验。

;

;目前加沙的战斗结束后，哈勒维将军作为南方司令部和;以色列国防军;整体负责人的角色将受到密切关注。哈马斯十月份的突然袭击显示出情报收集方面的严重失误。哈勒维将军是第一位承担责任的高级官员，他在 10 月 12 日表示，“以色列国防军负责国家及其公民的安全”，并且在袭击发生当天早上，“我们失败了” ”。接近他的人相信他打算在不久的将来辞职。但首先他要打最后一场战争。 ;■;

;;;;当英国公务员第一次了解法律是如何制定的时，他们是给定一个棋盘游戏。 “立法？！”由负责起草政府立法的议会法律顾问办公室制定。玩家们一边掷骰子、移动筹码，一边引导白厅和议会的立法。他们翻牌揭示了系统的障碍。 “忘记表示女王的同意。后退2格。” “需要新的计划动议。错过了一个转弯。”第一个将自己的政策变成国家法律的玩家获胜。

;

;与许多家庭游戏一样，议会的许多管理程序是习惯的产物，而不是铁律的产物。规则是可以改变的。可以切角。这就是现在正在发生的事情。议会最重要的工作是审查立法，但它却忽视了这一点。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这不是橡皮图章正文。 11 月 7 日国王演讲中提出的法案不会在没有反对的情况下获得通过。首相的提问一如既往地喧闹。叛乱分子仍然在深夜投票中羞辱他们的领导人。但对抗的场面掩盖了这样一个事实：议员们花在对拟议立法进行细致审查的时间越来越少。法律往往会被议会快速通过。一位趾高气扬的高管有时会将审查视为一种不便。这不仅在宪法上是令人反对的。它还具有实际成本。这是一个关于立法机制如何在几乎未被注意到的情况下开始失效的故事。

;

;深思熟虑的立法的一些障碍是结构性的。政府必须将立法纳入紧迫的时间表。因此，他们习惯性地抵制接受法案修正案。内阁办公室的立法手册警告部长们，必须“将变化保持在最低限度”，因为每一项变化都会拖延进展，请注意;杰西·萨金特;和智库政府研究所的杰克·潘内尔在最近的一份报告中说道。出于同样的原因，政府通常不愿在议会程序开始之前公布法案草案。萨金特女士发现，自 1997 年以来，每次会议平均只有八分之一的法案经过了立法前审查。

;

;第二个问题在于法案委员会，该委员会的目的是听取证据并逐条进行审查。在法案通过议会时对其进行严格审查。许多;国会议员;将其视为一种苦差事。对拟议法律真正感兴趣的独立思想者不太可能被党鞭挑选。由此产生的争论是党派之争，而且是草率的。按照惯例，主要宪法法案和其他一些法案都在主议院的“全体委员会”中听取。这允许所有;MP;都有发言权，但不利于仔细的文本审查。在 2015 年至 2021 年间的 177 项法案中，其中 73% 根本没有经过口头证据听证会。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;这些长期存在的问题因其他趋势而变得更加复杂。议会制定的立法比以往任何时候都多：法案和法定文书的数量从 1911 年的 760 页增加到 2009 年数据系列结束时的 15,200 多页（也许打印机只是卡住了）。移民和福利的监管制度变得更加复杂。英国退欧让威斯敏斯特负责制定密集的<小>;欧盟;规则手册。

;

;然而，下议院正试图在更短的时间内做更多的事情。 1988 年，它的开会时间为 173 天，但 2021 年仅开会 147 天。同期，平均开会时间从 9 小时 4 分钟减少到 7 小时 37 分钟，部分原因是进行了明智的改革，使该场所更加开放。家庭友善。

;

;这些较短的工作时间也有不同的用途。众议院花在政府立法上的时间比例从 2005-06 年 41% 的近期峰值下降到 6 月最近一次会议的 20%。紧急问题——部长被立即传唤到议会的程序，几乎总是对当天的头条新闻发表评论——数量激增，从 2007-08 年的 4 个增加到 2021-22 年的 104 个。威斯敏斯特大厅辩论是 1999 年为;议员;引入的非立法会议，旨在表达他们喜爱的事业，他们花在辩论上的时间比例有所增加。

;
;

;国家

;

;;国会议员的工作已经变得类似于“超级议员”的工作，为他们的选区游说，而不是关心国家大局的立法者。 2017 年，专注于议会的研究机构 Hansard Society 对公众进行了民意调查，询问他们认为<小>;议员;应该如何打发时间。 “制定法律”排在第八位，低于“在下议院代表当地人民的观点”和“参加当地公共会议和活动”。 2010年至2019年间，代表其出生地区选区的;议员;比例从45%上升至52%，其中2019年新当选的议员比例为60%。

;

;媒体格局的变化意味着雄心勃勃的<小>;议员;在审查立法方面获得的认可度低于他们的前任。直到二十年前，许多大报都有由全职“画廊”记者撰写的“议会的昨天”页面。现在注意力集中在其他地方。 “激励结构失调：[<小>;国会议员;]不会因为成为选区立法的良好监督者而获得任何荣誉或好处，”汉萨德协会的露丝·福克斯说。

;

;政治家也缺乏专家的支持。 ;MP;的人员配置预算旨在支持四名全职助理，最高级助理的薪酬上限为 56,312 英镑（69,000 美元）。许多人都很年轻；营业额高。相比之下，一名美国国会议员最多可以雇用 18 名全职工作人员，其中通常包括立法专家。上议院议员根本没有带薪个人研究人员。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这种弱化的审查制度受到了两次巨大的冲击。英国脱欧意味着英国政府需要争分夺秒地重写法规，为脱离<小>;欧盟;做好准备。 Covid-19 迫使立法者采取行动 ;甚至更快;。

;

;很少有人质疑速度的必要性。但英国脱欧公投引入了尖锐而激进的政治，议会的审查不是为选民服务，而是对选民的背叛。人们越来越担心，尤其是上议院的高级成员，危机时期的立法方式已成为一种新的运作方式。公务员表示，covid-19 和英国脱欧改变了部长们对正确起草法案所需时间的预期。自 2015 年以来当选的一代;议员;几乎不知道有什么不同。

;

;“至少三年来，部长们似乎一直将立法视为一系列政党政治广播，”前下议院最高级职员利斯万勋爵说。由下议院领袖担任主席的内阁部长委员会的任务是在法律草案进入系统之前对其进行审查。 “但如今，这种感觉似乎非常柔和。部长们根本不会因为他们的立法愿望而被送上被告席，”他说。

;
;;

;近年来越来越多的法案在一天内完成了主要的下议院阶段（二读和三读），几乎消除了进行有意义的审查的机会。一些匆忙的例子是合理的：通过covid-19立法或在女王去世后改变王室。

;

;其他人则不太情有可原。莉兹·特拉斯 (Liz Truss) 政府于 2022 年推出的《能源价格法案》支撑了一项 780 亿英镑的全民家庭和企业补贴计划。分析师和国会议员提出了成本低得多的目标设计，但那年夏天的保守党领导权竞争挤掉了适当的政策工作。 2020 年 12 月 30 日，实施鲍里斯·约翰逊脱欧贸易协议的法案在一天之内就获得了下议院和上议院的批准；相比之下，1992 年《马斯特里赫特条约》的批准花了 400 多天的时间。

;

;由于仓促，法律的细节正在稍后制定。特别是，部长们今天要求获得更广泛的权力，以便他们在明天制定政策。二级立法是部长们通过称为“法定文书”的法规制定的法律，并根据议会法案赋予他们的权力制定。传统上，主要立法用于制定政策（例如新的刑事犯罪），次要立法则用于确定其实施（例如设定罚款水平）。但这些边界从未被精确界定，而且边界的日益广泛使用促使上议院在 2021 年发出警告，“独裁政府”正在从议会手中夺取权力。

;

;“骨架法案”为部长们提供了制定政策的框架权力，但很少有关于具体内容的线索，但在英国脱欧时期，当部长们准备接受旧的<小>;欧盟;在渔业和化学品等领域的力量。但它们的使用已经成为一种模式的一部分。雅各布·里斯爵士宣称，《罢工（最低服务水平）法》是一项旨在在劳资纠纷期间维持火车和学校运行的法律，“几乎如此枯燥，以至于我们怀疑骨头的碎片是否被野生动物偷走了并埋在某个地方” -莫格，保守党<小>;议员;。

;
;

;骨架法案通常依赖于“亨利八世”的权力，该权力因都铎国王通过公告进行统治的习惯而得名。这些条款规定部长们可以通过发布二级立法来修改过去甚至未来的议会法案。前司法部门负责人法官勋爵在最近的一次演讲中宣称，这种情况已经变得如此普遍，以至于“当议会的一项法案省略亨利八世条款时，这只是因为该部门中的某个人没有按下法律上的相关按钮”。电脑。”前保守党大臣布兰卡斯拉勋爵抱怨说，自英国脱欧以来，部门律师出于“以防万一”的考虑，一直在“将它们附加到零散的小法案上”。目前议会正在审议一项旨在防止公共机构参与抵制英国盟友的法案，其中包含五个单独的亨利八世条款。 《网络安全法》包含20多个条款。单独来看，这些条款都是合理的；总的来说，他们指出政府在立法过程中寻求捷径。

;

;法定文书受到的审查甚至比主要立法还要少。它们被提交给议会并由立法者委员会进行筛选，但关于它们的辩论可能只持续几分钟或几秒钟。它们不能被修改，只能被否决，这种情况很少见。下议院上次阻止一项法定文书是在 1979 年。上议院上次这样做是在 2015 年。2019 年做出的到 2050 年实现净零排放的法律承诺可能是英国本世纪做出的最昂贵的政策决定。它是在下议院经过 90 分钟的辩论后，未经投票，利用 2008 年《气候变化法案》中创建的机制，通过一项法定文书制定的。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;根据称为“确认”的程序，一些成文法文书一旦部长签署就成为法律；立法者稍后对此进行投票。 《经济学人》对议会数据的审查表明，这种技术最近的使用更加广泛——从 1997-2019 年法定文书的 1.8% 增加到 2019-22 年的 8.1%。 Covid-19 是罪魁祸首。

;

;所有这种仓促行为都会导致决策缺乏依据。 <小>;国会议员;经常通过立法，但不知道其成本或收益。上议院最近的一份报告总结道，许多旨在量化拟议法定文书预期效果的影响评估“似乎是在最后一刻才拼凑在一起，以证明已经做出的决定是合理的”。英国内政部对《非法移民法案》的影响评估显示，将一个人驱逐到卢旺达将花费 169,000 英镑，而且只有阻止成千上万的人才具有成本效益。但直到 6 月 26 日，即下议院通过两个月后，它才发表。

;

;错误也在增加。 2022-23 年议会会议制定的法定文书中约有 11% 是为了纠正之前的起草错误，是上议院二级立法审查委员会认为人为错误可接受的 5% 阈值的两倍多。 “真正的问题是，这是一种非常方便的做事方式，”委员会成员、前首席大法官 Cwmgiedd 的托马斯勋爵 (Lord Thomas) 说道。 “当你因为方便而做某事时，这才是真正应该引起你担心的事情。”

;

;良好的审查历来依赖于下议院之间的相互作用，下议院在制定政策方面发挥着主导作用，以及未经选举产生的上议院，其重点是修改和微调立法。上议院的许多议员认为，他们被迫进行下议院逃避的基本审查，而政府对此的关注也较少。传统上，上议院会诱骗政府对有缺陷的立法进行修改。这一过程已经崩溃，导致上议院更频繁地直接投票反对政府。自2019年12月以来，它已造成370场失利，而2010-19赛季为268场。

;

;“当你看到大量的失败时，很大程度上是由于政府的顽固不化，而不是上议院的侵略性，”伦敦大学学院的梅格·拉塞尔教授说。有时他们会成功地迫使事情发生逆转。但更常见的情况是，当法案返回下议院时，修正案就被简单地否决了，并且没有任何影响。

;

;很少有保守党;议员;因为议会棋盘游戏的规则被遗忘而感到兴奋。 But should an election force them into opposition, the costs of a weakened Parliament will be more obvious to them. Labour Party officials insist they will restore discipline to drafting. But a Labour government would inherit a statute book packed with powers which could prove rather useful to ministers in a hurry.

;

;Take the Retained ;EU; Law (Revocation and Reform) Act, passed earlier this year, which creates wide-ranging powers for ministers to rewrite the regulations that predated Brexit. Its neo-Thatcherite architects hoped it would ignite a deregulatory Big Bang. But it might just as easily be used to strengthen trade-union rights or realign policies with those of the ;EU;. “These powers could sit there for decades, being used by governments who may take an entirely different approach,” says Dr Fox of the Hansard Society. “That does not seem to compute at all with ministers.” The rules of the legislative game exist for the benefit of all the players. When they are bent, everyone ends up losing. ■

; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 18:57:02 +0800 Will America pull the plug on Israel’s invasion of Gaza? | Middle East & Africahttps://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/11/07/will-america-pull-the-plug-on-israels-invasion-of-gaza ;
;
;

;;I;;T WAS HARDLY; a warm welcome, although that no doubt came as little surprise. Antony Blinken, America's secretary of state, spent the past few days shuttling across the Middle East, his second such trip since the start of the Gaza war on October 7th. In Amman his Jordanian counterpart, Ayman Safadi, told Mr Blinken to “stop this madness”. The language he heard in private across the region was even tougher. His meeting with Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, lasted less than an hour and ended with no joint statement. Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey did not bother to meet him at all.

;

;Mr Blinken's chilly reception was one sign of mounting anger at Israel's war in Gaza. Now in its second month, it has killed more than 10,000 Palestinians and damaged or destroyed more than 11% of the buildings in the enclave. It has enraged the Arab world, inflamed Western capitals and drawn condemnation from many world leaders.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;Read all our coverage of the war between Israel and Hamas;

;
;

;Israeli generals still talk about waging a long campaign that will last up to a year. On November 7th Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu told ;ABC; News that Israel would be in charge of Gaza's security for an “indefinite period”. In practice, though, what Israeli officers call their “window of legitimacy” is probably far shorter. How fast that window closes will depend largely on America, which supplies Israel with munitions, diplomatic support and an aid package worth perhaps $14bn. If Joe Biden wants the war to end, Israel will be hard pressed to ignore him.

;

;So far, he does not. Although he now supports “humanitarian pauses” to allow more aid to enter Gaza, Mr Biden has rejected calls for an outright ceasefire. But administration officials have made clear, in a series of leaks, that they doubt Israel has a coherent exit strategy in Gaza. They complain that Mr Netanyahu is barely willing to discuss the topic, and say they want to put their concerns on the record now lest the war end badly. To think a war risks becoming a quagmire but to support it nonetheless is an untenable position—especially when American voters agree.

;

;A poll by ;The Economist; and YouGov found that a plurality of Americans (41%) believe Mr Biden is handling the war badly. A Quinnipiac survey of registered voters found that 51% of independents and 66% of people aged 18 to 34 disapprove of his policy. His ratings have plummeted amongst Arab-American voters, which could hurt him next year in crucial swing states like Michigan. Sources in Washington think it will still be several more weeks before Mr Biden pivots to talk of a truce—but do not doubt that he will make such a shift.

;

;Arab states certainly hope so. Fears of a multi-front war, which were acute in the days after Hamas's massacre, have eased. Hizbullah, the Lebanese Shia militia, continues to fire rockets daily at Israel, but Hassan Nasrallah, the group's leader, signalled in a speech on November 3rd that he was not yet interested in all-out war. The Houthis, a Shia militant group in Yemen, have lobbed drones and missiles at Israel but are too far away to pose a strategic threat.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Many autocrats across the Middle East would be happy to see Israel smash Hamas. But they are also nervous that the war will mobilise their subjects, many of whom are already restive about awful economic conditions. This adds to pressure on both America, which has heard their fears for weeks now, and Israel, which is keen to preserve its recent diplomatic gains in the Arab world.

;

;So far, most countries have made do with symbolic rebukes of Israel. On November 2nd the lower house of Bahrain's parliament announced that the country would recall its ambassador from Israel. The chamber has few powers; recalling ambassadors is not one of them. Envoys from both countries had gone home weeks earlier. Parliament, in a fit of populist politics, made it seem as if lawmakers had decreed their return. Officials in both Bahrain and Israel say diplomatic ties remain intact.

;

;Four days later King Abdullah of Jordan announced that his air force had dropped a shipment of medical aid into Gaza. Jordan would not have taken such action without seeking Israel's approval, which the Israeli army later confirmed it had indeed given. By omitting that detail from his announcement, though, the king could act as if he had challenged Israel's blockade of Gaza.

;

;Such gestures do not earn much goodwill at home, however. Even the United Arab Emirates (;UAE;), Israel's closest Arab ally, has grown increasingly critical (at least in public). Anwar Gargash, a foreign-policy adviser to the ;UAE;'s president, said at a conference on November 4th that America should push for a ceasefire, “the quicker the better”.

;

;Then there is Israel itself. Morale is high in the army, and Israelis seem willing to accept far more casualties than they normally would (34 Israeli soldiers have been killed so far). But the public is furious with a prime minister more concerned with his political survival than with battlefield strategy. Protesters gathered at Mr Netanyahu's house on November 4th to demand his resignation.

;

;Another question is the economy. The month-long Lebanon war in 2006 cost around 9.5bn shekels ($2bn at the time), whereas the last big Gaza conflict in 2014 cost 7bn shekels. This one may be even costlier. The Bank of Israel thinks the government's deficit will climb to 3% of ;GDP; next year, compared with a 0.6% surplus in 2022; some outside analysts put the estimate above 5%. Mobilising 360,000 reservists has also left parts of the Israeli economy with a shortage of workers, even if some of them have now been sent home.

;

;Israeli officials hope that the fierce bombardment of the war's first month is now giving way to a new phase. Gaza city is surrounded by the ;IDF;, and ground troops and armour are drawing closer to the area where the ;IDF; says Hamas has its headquarters and where a nucleus of its fighters and leadership are holed up underground. If the ;IDF; can soon destroy these facilities and kill large numbers of militants, some officers believe that it will have partially met its mission of depleting Hamas's ability to run Gaza. The war would then move into a more limited campaign of ground raids.

;

;That could ease international pressure, which spikes every time Israeli jets bomb a bakery or a refugee camp, and ease pressure on the economy by allowing the army to release some reservists. The Israelis also recognise that relieving the humanitarian crisis in Gaza could buy more time. On November 6th the ;UAE; announced that it would set up a 150-bed field hospital in Gaza, a move co-ordinated with Israel. Mr Netanyahu now says he is open to “tactical little pauses, an hour here, an hour there” to allow more aid to enter.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Arguably, though, the biggest challenge to Israel's international legitimacy is Mr Netanyahu himself. His government is stacked with radicals. Amichai Eliyahu, the heritage minister, recently suggested dropping a nuclear bomb on Gaza. Zvi Sukkot, the new head of a parliamentary committee that oversees the occupied West Bank, is a far-right ideologue who has been investigated by Israel's Shin Bet for his alleged extremist activity.

;

;When they met in Ramallah, Mr Abbas told Mr Blinken that the Palestinian Authority, which controls parts of the West Bank, could return to Gaza to govern the enclave after the war. Such an outcome would please both the Israeli army and the Americans.

;

;But Mr Abbas added that it would only happen “within the framework of a comprehensive political solution”—in other words, as a step towards a two-state solution, which Mr Netanyahu has spent his entire political career fighting against. If he remains in office, there will be no serious talk of an endgame in Gaza. America's patience will run out and Israel will find its room for manoeuvre increasingly limited. ;■;

; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 18:57:02 +0800 The deadly missile race in the Middle East | Middle East & Africahttps://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/11/07/the-deadly-missile-race-in-the-middle-east ;
;
;

;;T;;HE BALLISTIC; missiles that arced from Yemen to Israel on October 31st set several records. They probably travelled farther than any other ballistic missile fired as an act of aggression, having crossed at least 1,600km. They were intercepted by Israel's Arrow missile-defence system above the Negev desert. It was the first time that Arrow, deployed for 23 years, had taken out a surface-to-surface missile. It was also the first ever combat interception in space, according to two Israeli officials. The incident is a small illustration of how the proliferation of missiles with growing range and precision is changing the military landscape of the Middle East.

;

;Missiles have been part of war in the region for over 50 years. The Soviet Scud, a workhorse of the rocket world, was first fired in the final stages of the Yom Kippur war of 1973 against Israel. Huge numbers of Scuds were fired by Iran and Iraq in the so-called war of the cities in the 1980s. By one estimate, 90% of the 5,000 missiles let loose in combat between 1945 and 2017 were fired in the Middle East. Now the threat is metastasising in two ways. More people have access to more missiles. And the missiles themselves are becoming qualitatively better.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;Read all of our coverage of the war between Israel and Hamas;

;
;

;Start with the proliferation. In the 1950s Egypt began building ballistic missiles with the help of Nazi scientists. Israel followed, with French help. From the 1960s to the 1980s Soviet missiles flooded into Egypt, Iraq, Libya, Syria and other states. China supplied Saudi Arabia and Turkey. North Korea helped Iran, Yemen and the United Arab Emirates. Later, America, Britain and France sent advanced missiles of their own. The result is that 11 countries in the region now have ballistic missiles (those which fly in a parabolic arc) or cruise missiles (which use plane-like engines to fly on flatter trajectories) with ranges of more than 250km, estimates Hassan Elbahtimy of King's College London.

;

;Just as important is the fact that states no longer have a monopoly on the technology. Over the past 20 years Iran has supplied drones, rockets and missiles, as well as the know-how to make them, to Hamas in Gaza, the Houthis in Yemen, sundry militia in Iraq and Syria and, most notably, Hizbullah in Lebanon. In 2007 Hamas had several hundred rockets, according to Israeli estimates. That jumped to 10,000 in 2014 and then tripled to 30,000 in 2021. Hizbullah's more sophisticated arsenal went from around 15,000 missiles in 2006, the year it fought a war with Israel, to some 150,000 today. Around 400 of those are long-range missiles which can hit anywhere in Israel.

;

;The result is that armed groups now pose a level of conventional military threat that only states could have done 20 years ago. “The danger of a two-front war for Israel”, argues Bruce Hoffman of the Council on Foreign Relations, “begins to assume existential dimensions.” Larger stockpiles enable larger and longer-lasting salvos. In the first Gulf war, Saddam Hussein's Iraq fired on average around one Scud a day at Israel for just over a month. Hamas, though armed with punier rockets, went from a peak of 192 launches per day during a war in 2014 to 470 on the first day of a major flare-up in 2021 (that excludes smaller mortars). On October 7th alone it fired at least 2,200.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;Numbers, though, are not the main problem. Hamas has scored relatively few direct hits on built-up areas. That would suggest Iron Dome, a missile-defence system for short-range rockets (pictured in action), is still intercepting around 90% of its targets, as it did in previous wars with Gaza. Of the 1,400 Israelis killed since October 7th, only four have died as a result of rocket strikes, according to a senior Israel Defence Forces (;IDF;) officer who spoke to ;The Economist;. Israel's missile-defence systems are world-class. Two of those were from heart-failure while rushing to bomb-shelters. The problem is that the missiles are getting better.

;

;Consider Saddam's Scuds. “You have a system that's very expensive, very complicated to operate and terribly inaccurate,” says Fabian Hinz of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, a think-tank. Those Scuds had a circular error probable (;CEP;) of more than two kilometres, meaning only half the missiles fired would be expected to land within that distance of the impact point. That made them good for three things, says Mr Hinz: showing off at parades, terrorising cities or delivering nuclear weapons.

;

;In a paper published in 2021, Michael Horowitz, now a senior Pentagon official, and Lauren Kahn of Georgetown University showed that in 1990 just nine countries had “smart” precision-guided bombs, which use a mixture of inertial navigation and satellite signals to find their targets. Even large powers like China and India, and most ;NATO; countries, lacked the capability. Then the technology went global: 22 countries had it by 2000, and 56 by 2017.

;

;That included Iran. The Shahab-1 missile, a Scud knock-off, which Iran used to strike Iraq-based militants in the 1990s and early 2000s had a ;CEP; of around half a kilometre. Today the Fateh-110, an Iranian-designed family of missiles, is thought to have a ;CEP; of well under 35 metres, and perhaps as low as five metres with a reliable satellite signal—good enough to hit a large vehicle. It showed that off in January 2020 when it retaliated for the assassination of an Iranian general by attacking American troops in Iraq and scoring six direct hits on missile hangars. A suspected Iranian drone and cruise-missile attack the previous year on Saudi oil facilities was similarly on-target.

;
;

;“That strike had huge geopolitical ramifications,” says Mr Hinz. Previously, most states that wanted to hit enemies far away needed an expensive air force; an unguided missile would be useless beyond 1,000km. “Now you have actors without an air force—or with a really terrible air force, like Iran—being able to hit the depth of an adversary,” he says. “That changes the strategic calculus.” The 2019 and 2020 strikes demonstrated that Iran, and its proxies, had a serious conventional deterrent against Israel, America and others.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Greater range also means the ability to attack Israel from a wider range of countries. Short-range missiles launched from Israel's doorstep in the Levant will always be cheaper and thus affordable in the larger numbers needed for bigger barrages or longer wars. But Yemen is still a useful launchpad. It remains unclear whether the Houthis or their Iranian patrons launched the October 31st attack. That is part of the appeal. Iran's revolutionary guards can blame strikes on Houthi militants. And if Israel were to retaliate in Yemen, the risk of escalation and political fallout would be lower than that of a war over Lebanon or Iraq.

;

;Finally, precision also poses a profound challenge for missile defences. Iron Dome and other Israeli defences work by calculating where a missile is headed and intercept it only if it is landing somewhere important, like a populated area or military base. In 2006 Hizbullah's arsenal was almost entirely unguided, so many rockets could be safely ignored. But over the past decade Iran has successfully sent hundreds of guidance kits, which turn regular missiles into precision ones, to Lebanon, say Israel officials, despite sporadic Israeli air strikes in Syria to interdict those supplies.

;

;That means, in a future war—one that Israeli officials reckon is inevitable—a far greater proportion of incoming missiles will have both a specific intended target and a good shot at reaching it. Israel will have to expend far more interceptors in consequence. Each Iron Dome interceptor costs around $100,000. Those for David's Sling, a separate system which tackles larger rockets, costs several times that. Israel may have to focus on strategic sites, like headquarters and air bases, rather than cities.

;

;One way to adapt is to conserve interceptors by refining the algorithm which predicts where rockets are likely to land. Another is to use electronic warfare to jam navigation signals, as Israel is already doing—to the confusion of drivers relying on phone apps to get around. A third is to focus on cheaper means of interception. Israel has conducted several tests of a laser-based system known as Iron Beam. Its operational integration into the existing missile-defence batteries will not occur during this war, though, and it has shortcomings, such as cumbersome machinery and limited effectiveness in overcast conditions.

;

;Israel can also call on allies. America has a large X-band radar in Israel's Negev desert and its warships shot down a barrage from Yemen on October 19th. One missile from that barrage was even intercepted by Saudi Arabia, which does not have diplomatic relations with Israel but shares radar via America. In June last year Israel said it had joined the Middle East Air Defence Alliance (;MEAD;), an American-led scheme that includes Arab countries.

;

;“The success of this technology is that it's been adaptable over the years to a range of different threats coming from different directions,” says Yair Ramati, an Israeli engineer, one of the original developers of Arrow and a former head of the missile-defence directorate at Israel's defence ministry. “For over 30 years, there's been an arms-race in which Israel's enemies have been constantly building up their arsenals and we've been developing our defence systems.” That race shows no sign of slowing down. ;■;

; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 18:57:02 +0800 The fall of WeWork shows the deepening cracks in real estate | Businesshttps://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/07/the-fall-of-wework-shows-the-deepening-cracks-in-real-estate ;
;
;

;;S;;ince it was; founded in 2010, WeWork has not once turned a profit. For years its cash-torching ways went unchallenged, thanks to the reality-distorting powers of its flamboyant founder, Adam Neumann, who succeeded in convincing investors, most notably SoftBank, that it was not an office-rental business but a zippy tech firm on a mission to “elevate the world's consciousness”. At the height of the silliness in early 2019, in the lead-up to an initial public offering (;IPO;), the company was valued at $47bn.

;

;The unravelling began soon after, as outside investors balked at its frothy valuation and questioned an unorthodox governance arrangement that gave Mr Neumann an iron grip on the company. The ;IPO; was shelved, and Mr Neumann was offered $1.7bn to leave. Sandeep Mathrani, a real-estate veteran brought in to run the company, did his best to right the ship by cutting costs and renegotiating leases. In 2021 he succeeded in listing the firm through a special-purpose acquisition company, at a valuation of $9bn. Yet his efforts were undone by the slump in the office market brought on by the pandemic and an enduring shift towards remote working. On November 6th WeWork, which leases office space in 777 locations across 39 countries, filed for bankruptcy.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It is not the only property business in turmoil. Days earlier, on the other side of the Atlantic, René Benko, a once celebrated Austrian property magnate, was ousted from Signa, the €23bn ($25bn) property empire he built. Its portfolio includes the Chrysler Building in New York; the ;K;a;D;e;W;e, a posh department store in West Berlin; and a stake in Selfridges, another ritzy temple of consumption in London; as well as luxury hotels, high-end developments and a grab-bag of other retail businesses.

;

;The two cases are not identical. Unlike WeWork, Signa has not declared bankruptcy, though it faces a liquidity crunch, and has brought in a prominent German insolvency expert, Arndt Geiwitz, to take the reins. And unlike Mr Neumann, Mr Benko, a self-made high-school dropout who started his career converting attics into penthouses in his hometown of Innsbruck, was involved with Signa right up until his weekend ousting. After a conviction for bribery in 2012, he stepped back from day-to-day operational duties, but continued to sit on the company's advisory board. He gave his blessing to the appointment of Mr Geiwitz, who helped steer Lufthansa, Germany's national airline, through an insolvency. (Mr Neumann, meanwhile, has been reduced to sniping at WeWork's collapse from the sidelines, complaining that the company “failed to take advantage of a product that is more relevant today than ever before”.)

;

;Yet the rise and fall of the two empires share similarities. For one, both relied on risky bets that went sour in a world of higher interest rates and slumping property markets. As he built his empire, Mr Benko accumulated a mountain of debt in order to purchase new assets while maintaining juicy dividends. That model worked only as long as interest rates were low and the value of prime property continued to rise. ; Wed, 08 Nov 2023 18:57:02 +0800 From hypersonic missiles to undersea drones, the PLA is making leaps | Special reporthttps://www.economist.com/special-report/2023/11/06/from-hypersonic-missiles-to-undersea-drones-the-pla-is-making-leaps ;
;
;

;;X;;i Jinping learned; a lot from his first job. As secretary to Geng Biao, a vice-premier and defence minister, from 1979 to 1982, he handled sensitive documents and joined top-level conclaves. He travelled abroad for the first time. And he spent countless hours listening to Geng—a former general and ambassador—as they shuttled between meetings in a chauffeur-driven Mercedes or unwound playing a game of ;weiqi;, also known as Go.

;

;More importantly, Mr Xi witnessed firsthand the parlous state of the ;PLA;. It had just been fought to a stalemate by Vietnam. It was still using old Soviet weapons technology, some of it dating to the second world war. And despite China opening diplomatic ties with America, Geng had failed to persuade it to supply missiles and other lethal arms during a visit there in 1980 (although he did get a private White House screening of “The Empire Strikes Back”).

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Four decades on, Mr Xi leads a country that can design and produce almost all of the modern weaponry that it needs. His mostly state-run defence industry manufactures nuclear-powered submarines, stealth fighters and a formidable arsenal of missiles. The Pentagon says that the ;PLA; has deployed a medium-range hypersonic missile that can fly on the atmosphere's edge and change course to evade defences. It also says that in 2021 China tested a longer-range version that could one day carry a nuclear bomb to America's mainland (China says it was a space vehicle).

;

;And yet Chinese armaments still suffer technical flaws, supply-chain problems and development delays. Its ten big state-owned arms-makers are overstaffed, poorly run and prone to conceal mistakes. A drive to involve the private sector has yet to bear fruit. And for some key components, China is still dependent on other countries whose reliability as suppliers is in doubt.

;

;Corruption persists, too, despite Mr Xi's efforts. The ;PLA; revamp he started in 2016 included establishing a new Equipment Development Department and strict rules on ordering and testing weapons. But this July that department acknowledged graft had persisted. It called for tip-offs of violations since 2017 including favouritism, collusion, cover-ups and “actively leaking secrets”.

;

;Some Western officials believe that may be linked to the disappearance since August of General Li Shangfu, who was sacked as defence minister in October after seven months in the job. He led the Equipment Development Department from 2017 to 2022.

;

;Russian roulette

;

;Even before the war in Ukraine, the ;PLA; had suggested that it was falling short of its goals, with military publications often repeating Mr Xi's assertion that it did not yet have the weapons to win a high-tech war. Those concerns have intensified as Ukrainian forces have exposed flaws in Russian arms, many of which China has bought and copied since being hit with Western arms embargoes after the ;PLA;'s killing of pro-democracy protesters in 1989.

;
;;

;The vulnerability of Russian tanks, armoured vehicles and warships to portable missile systems and drones has been a particular concern. “We must promptly make corresponding improvements to the protection of relevant equipment to minimise combat losses,” said a defence industry journal in October 2022.

;

;Mr Xi also appears unnerved by American curbs on exports to China of chips and other tech with military uses. Addressing ;PLA; officers in March, he said China's defence industry needed to focus more on innovation, self-reliance and “winning wars”.

;

;Now an economic slowdown could squeeze military spending at the same time as more of it is being used to sweeten benefits for recruits. “We're still far from matching America,” Senior Colonel Zhang Chi of the ;PLA; National Defence University tells ;The Economist;. “Our biggest problem is that China's economy needs to develop more. We just don't have the money.”

;

;Take that with a fistful of salt. China's 2023 military budget is $225bn (compared with America's $817bn) but is thought to exclude key items such as arms imports. China gets more bang for its buck, too, with lower labour and other costs. Its spies have stolen lots of foreign military tech. And its universities produce many more doctorates in science, technology, engineering and mathematics than do America's.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;That has helped China to take the lead in research into some high-tech areas, such as hypersonic weapons and underwater drones, some experts say. But it has yet to master design and mass production of some older technology which, as the war in Ukraine has shown, could still play a key role in any near-term conflict. Engines have been a particular problem.

;

;Consider China's ;J;-20 stealth fighters, which first flew in 2011. For years most used a Russian engine. By 2022 that had been replaced with a Chinese one, the ;WS;-10, which is less durable and has limited capacity for supersonic flight without using an afterburner. That makes the jet much less stealthy—a serious problem when anti-aircraft systems can make non-stealthy aircraft almost unusable, as Russia has found in Ukraine.

;

;Then, in late June, video footage surfaced on Chinese social media appearing to show a test flight of the same stealth fighter with a more powerful, reliable and fuel-efficient Chinese engine, known as the ;WS;-15. Chinese experts hailed it as a breakthrough. Some suggested it was already in mass production and could match the Pratt & Whitney engine on America's stealthy ;F;-22.

;

;Yet Zhang Yong of the Aero Engine Corporation of China, which makes military aircraft engines, sounded more cautious at a conference three months earlier. “Technological bottlenecks” on the ;WS;-15 were resolved but supply chains for its components needed to be improved, he said. He also suggested that China still imported 2% of the roughly 90,000 components for the older ;WS;-10.

;

;Even if the ;J;-20's new engine really does rival the ;F;-22's, it is noteworthy that China took so long to match an engine that began development in the 1980s and stopped production in 2013. “It brings Chinese engines squarely into the late 20th century,” says Jeremiah Gertler, a military aviation specialist at America's Centre for Strategic and International Studies. The gap is narrowing, he says, but “engine development in the West has moved on”.

;

;Marine engines also have been a challenge. Many ;PLA; ships use Ukrainian, French or German engines made under licence in China. Several Chinese diesel-electric submarines use German engines, too, while nuclear-powered models are thought to rely heavily on Russian technology.

;

;Marine and aircraft engines accounted for more than 55% of China's arms imports between 2017 and 2022, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, which monitors the global arms trade. That was a worry for the ;PLA; even before the war in Ukraine. “In certain areas, we're still dependent on foreign suppliers,” wrote Tang Guoyong, a ;PLA; researcher, in 2020. “This poses significant risks in future warfare.”

;

;It is fair to say Ukraine's future as a supplier is in doubt. Russia might be willing to provide more advanced technology given its growing dependence on China. But its ability to fulfil orders could be impaired. European suppliers, meanwhile, are under increasing American pressure to stop supplying anything that the ;PLA; could use.

;

;That became apparent last year when Germany blocked the export of a German engine for a Chinese submarine sold to Thailand. China offered one of its own but Thailand refused, saying the engine was “not proven”, an indication that it had not yet been used on a submarine. Thailand did send experts to China to investigate but shelved the deal in October and proposed buying a Chinese frigate instead. The saga indicated a “puzzling bottleneck” in China's technological capabilities, says Sarah Kirchberger, an expert on the ;PLA; navy at the German Maritime Institute.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;China's reputation as an arms exporter has been damaged, too, by recent reports of defects in equipment sold to countries including Bangladesh, Myanmar, Pakistan and Nigeria. China does not export its best kit. But some recent problems affect the ;PLA;'s own inventory. One Chinese study of its military ;UAV;s in 2020 found that the drones “often fail to meet actual combat needs” due to technical faults.

;

;Arms-makers the world over are notorious for cost overruns, delays and defects. But China's problems are rooted in its politics and history. Its defence industry was modelled on the Soviet Union's and retains many similar flaws, including a highly compartmentalised structure born of an obsession with secrecy, with strict divisions between research and production units.

;

;China's defence-research institutes are also deeply influenced by central planning, writes Ren Zhen of the China Academy of Engineering Physics, which helps develop nuclear weapons. Complex organisation and severe internal friction make the institutes “incompatible with the modern goal of achieving fast and high-quality project results”. He also cited insufficient pay in the sector.

;

;None of that stopped China from making huge strides in defence technology in recent years. It will make more. But the pace of progress across the board is not as impressive as headlines suggest. And complex new challenges have emerged from the war in Ukraine. Mr Xi says he wants the ;PLA; to be “basically” modernised by 2035. From where he's sitting, that is still an ambitious target. ;■;

;;W;;HAT MIGHTY; armour Donald Trump wears. ;
;;

;Even among Biden fans, ;doubt is creeping in;. ;

;In Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, they found Mr Trump to be leading among registered voters by a margin of at least four points.他们发现拜登仅在威斯康星州领先两个百分点。在令人失望的顶线之下，交叉表包含了更多令人担忧的发现。 In these critical states 42% of Hispanic and 22% of African-American voters said they would vote for Mr Trump, which, if true, would mark the collapse of the minority support that Democrats had relied on for decades.

;Voters also said they trusted Mr Trump to do a better job on handling the economy (59% to 37% for Mr Biden);以及移民问题（53% 至 41%）；甚至在以色列-巴勒斯坦冲突上（50%对39%）。十分之七的选民表示，他们认为拜登先生太老了，无法成为一名有效的总统——其中包括大多数民主党人。 The polling was so inauspicious that David Axelrod, the prominent Democratic political strategist who helped to elect Barack Obama, gently suggested that Mr Biden should consider standing down.

;

;Should Democrats be in such a panic?他们可能首先尝试通过样本误差的变幻莫测来安慰自己。民意调查变得越来越困难，因为对民意调查机构做出回应的美国人越来越少，这使得构建具有代表性的选民样本变得非常困难。对于衡量非裔美国人或西班牙裔选民等人口亚群体的情绪尤其如此，这些群体的样本量甚至比民意调查中可能抽取的数千人还要小。 Yet other head-to-head polls show a tight contest, suggesting that the result is not an outlier.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The better argument for those who defend Mr Biden is that polls are a snapshot in time, and that public opinion drifts.正如政治学家克里斯托弗·韦莱齐恩 (Christopher Wlezien) 和威尔·詹宁斯 (Will Jennings) 在对数十个国家数十年选举的研究中发现的那样，提前一年进行的面对面民意调查对于预测最终结果几乎毫无用处。美国总统竞选通常势均力敌，大选前几个月的民意调查也趋于紧张。 “我们生活在一个应该看到八点转变的世界吗？” says John Sides, a political scientist at Vanderbilt University, pointing out that Mr Biden losing by five points in Michigan would be significantly worse than his victory margin of three points in 2020. “It doesn't seem plausible to me to assume you're going to get a swing as large as these polls imply…that's another reason for some degree of caution.”

;

;Yet this is plainly not where the Biden campaign hoped to be one year away from the election.他们最有可能的对手并没有致命的缺陷，而是看起来非常有可能当选。由于特朗普和拜登都是前总统，有关公众舆论转变的警告可能不那么适用。大多数美国人对他们已经形成了根深蒂固的看法，并且抵制改变。 In a memo distributed on November 2nd, Julie Rodriguez, Mr Biden's campaign manager, argued that “Team Biden-Harris is well-prepared to defeat whoever emerges from the extreme ;MAGA; Republicans' primary field”, citing the $91m in cash that the campaign already had in hand. ;;

;Those who eschew predictions based on early polls and instead place stock in fundamentals—like the president's approval rating and the state of the economy—should also be concerned.尽管拜登享有在任的优势，但根据数据新闻机构 FiveThirtyEight 的民调平均值，他的净支持率为 -16 点。 That is almost identical to Mr Trump's standing at this point of his presidency and five points behind Barack Obama (see chart).

;

;Another difficulty is age.拜登即将年满 81 岁，他的面容疲惫不堪，偶尔会说错话，这是可以理解的。考虑到马丁·艾米斯小说之外的时间箭头的方向，这些可能会变得更加引人注目。美国选民似乎对卡玛拉·哈里斯担任副总统不太放心，她的民意调查结果通常与她的老板一样糟糕，甚至更差。 None of which is to say that Mr Biden has been a bad president: his administration's approach to ;Israel's war with Hamas; is another reminder of how much the world benefits from having a competent, experienced team in the White House. Yet, come election time, that will not be enough.

;

;Mr Biden appears to have no intention of standing down, and the party appears to have no intention of throwing him over.那么他能做什么呢？有些事情，比如人的健康或经济的健康，取决于神灵（或概率，取决于你的信条）。其他因素，例如拜登竞选活动的力度，这将是一项耗资数十亿美元的行动，致力于提高他的公众地位，都在人类的控制范围内。总统将不得不吸引工人阶级选民，无论是白人还是非白人，他们一直倾向于共和党。他必须激发那些对政府的以色列政策感到恼火的进步人士的热情。年轻选民需要一些鼓励才能对年迈的总统产生热情。拜登先生的最佳投票率推动者将是他的对手，而许多美国人一直忽视他。特朗普的重新登场——包括他在法庭上斥责法官的热情——有望治愈他们的怀旧之情。 ;■;

;;我;;在《Skyfighters》中的场景;，由 ;解放军八一电影制片厂，空军某师师长要进行夜间模拟作战情况演练。他的年轻副手不同意，理由是能见度不好。此外，飞行员们正在休息（主要是在一家战斗机形状的酒吧，除了咖啡和果汁之外，似乎没有人喝任何东西）。

;

;对话实在是太糟糕了，更何况还有害羞的飞行员和活泼的鸟类学家之间的浪漫情节。但场面却引人注目。对于;PLA;来说，这就是领导力的运作方式。

;

;作为中国共产党的武装力量，成立于1927年，;PLA;一直保留着这一角色。自从。而且由于文职政党领导人从来不太信任他们穿制服的同志，关键决策一直是由;解放军;的党委做出，每个党委都由一名政治官员（通常称为政委）领导。

;

;;习近平认为“政治工作”与他要求解放军专注于战斗的要求之间并不冲突;

;

;大多数单位（以及海军舰艇）都有政治官员。他们向军队灌输思想、监控士气并监督晋升。但他们也可以干预行动并替换阵亡或受伤的指挥官。从技术上讲，政治官员与指挥官拥有同等权力，但往往拥有更大的影响力，因为他们领导着党委。

;

;这种混乱似乎迫切需要改革。相反，习近平寻求重振它。 2014年，他在福建省古田县主持召开了一次会议，85年前，毛泽东在古田县将军队的政治控制写入了党的学说中。习近平指出了解放军存在的十大“突出问题”，指出缺乏理想和革命精神。解决方案？ “政治工作只能加强。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;

;然而，在实践中，中国的体系充满了担忧。有问题。最令人震惊的是指挥官和政治官员之间的紧张关系。后者通常整个职业生涯都专注于政治工作，对行动问题的理解有限。

;

;在习近平的领导下，解放军相关出版物有时以严厉的措辞承认了这个问题。 。 《解放军日报》2016 年表示，一些政治官员“坐在会议厅里的次数多于作战室的次数，拿笔的次数多于持枪的次数，看文本的次数多于地图的次数”。训练中成为观察员，战斗中成为业余爱好者。”

;

;《解放军空军报》讲述了2018年一次演习中的跳伞事件。部队在着陆时造成多人伤亡，包括营长。政委接管了工作，但优先考虑的是与其他政治官员的协调，而不是手头的任务。演习中敌方获胜。

;

;解放军更新了2020年政治军官指导方针，重申政治军官与指挥员的平等地位，同时要求更加注重战斗力。但问题依然存在。军事科学院范静在2021年写道，仍然过于重视政治军官的说写能力，而不够重视战斗能力。

;

;混乱的指挥系统对最近开始定期巡逻的中国核导弹潜艇构成了特殊的挑战。由于他们必须能够从隐蔽地点进行核打击，因此他们要在水下呆上几个月，很少与总部联系。正是由于沟通方面的挑战，习近平可能会提前授权这些潜艇的指挥官在某些情况下发动攻击。但如果发生争议，就不清楚到底是船长还是政委说了算。

;
;
;
;
;
;;

;苏联在其武装部队（包括其核导弹潜艇）中也设有政治委员，但通常赋予指挥官最终权力。尽管如此，这些潜艇上的政委仍有权确保命令得到执行。苏联海军舰艇上的混乱并不少见。

;

;冷战最危险的时刻之一是古巴导弹危机期间，美国军队在马尾藻海包围了一艘苏联潜艇。由于无法联系到苏联指挥部，也不知道战争是否已经开始，这艘潜艇的三名高级军官就是否发射核弹头鱼雷争论不休。他们决定不这样做，并向美国人投降。

;

;解放军的另一个问题是对政治教育的日益关注。这可以包括阅读官方文本和演讲、写文章、观看视频和参加在线课程，主要集中在“习近平新时代中国特色社会主义思想”——中国领导人的浮夸意识形态学说——及其子集“习近平强军思想”。

;

;请看一名军官在其部队学习习近平重要讲话时的描述。他对《解放军日报》表示，“一些官兵认真阅读了讲话原文，写下了感想；有的梳理要点，准备系统深入学习；美国国防大学的菲利普·桑德斯估计，军队四分之一的时间花在政治工作上。 “显然习近平认为这是一个好的或必要的权衡，”他说。 “但是现在训练时间被缩短了，这肯定会对你们的行动准备产生一些不利影响。”

;

;即使从其本身的角度来看，习近平对政治工作的重视也没有达到预期的效果。此举本应有助于根除徐才厚和郭伯雄领导下解放军中普遍存在的违纪行为，徐才厚和郭伯雄在 2012 年退休之前实施了大规模的贿赂升职计划，是军队的两位最高级别的人物。 ” 。同时撤换司令员李玉超和政委徐忠波，这是不寻常的。一些人认为他们因腐败或泄露军事机密而受到调查。

;

;一种可能性是，他们的问题与习近平的核升级有关，这可能涉及准备更快地在导弹上安装弹头。一些人认为他想从“不首先使用”（只有在遭受核打击后才发动原子打击）的核态势转变为“警告后发射”（一旦检测到来袭核导弹就立即发射）。由于这可能需要火箭部队指挥官的事先授权，习近平可能重新审视了他们的政治可靠性。

;

;但他的清洗似乎超出了火箭部队的范围。 9月，另一位将军被解除解放军军事法院院长职务。随后，10月，李尚福将军被解除国防部长职务，此时距离任命仅七个月。自八月以来，他就没有在公开场合露面，美国官员认为他可能因涉嫌腐败而被拘留。

;
;
;
;
;;
;

;将军们的问题给习近平带来了不好的影响，他们是在习近平的领导下提拔的。他们还谈到了更深层次的问题。在习近平上台之前，收买升职和其他类似的不当行为在解放军非常普遍，以至于很少有高级军官是清白的。但他不可能在不严重削弱;解放军;高层的情况下将他们全部解雇，并在军事精英中树敌。

;

;他也不能放弃政委制度，因为他需要维持党对<小>;解放军;的控制。作为一位著名军事指挥官（兼政委）的儿子，他比大多数人更了解这一点。他在竞争党内最高职位的军人家庭中长大。他知道对毛泽东最严峻的挑战来自军事人物。作为国防部长的秘书，他看到了<小>;解放军;在毛泽东去世后的权力斗争中所扮演的角色。

;

;他也为苏联的崩溃所困扰，并将其归咎于苏联的崩溃克里姆林宫未能控制武装部队。他知道，1989 年解放军部队镇压北京的抗议活动时，一些人拒绝参加。一支世界一流的军队可能是习近平“中国梦”的核心。但让他夜不能寐的是担心<小>;解放军;不会为党辩护。 ;■;

;;F;;五年前;前，世界经济因石油价格翻两番而陷入困境，布雷顿森林固定汇率体系崩溃。英国对 20 世纪 70 年代动荡的反应在两个方面与其他发达国家不同。

;

;玛格丽特·撒切尔领导的保守党政府拥抱自由市场、高利率和飙升的汇率意味着伦敦以外的英国大部分地区以西欧最快的速度去工业化。我们与麻省理工学院的安娜·斯坦斯伯里 (Anna Stansbury) 共同撰写并于今年早些时候发表的一篇论文发现，只有东欧在后共产主义转型期间的经历可以与 20 世纪 80 年代英国各地区的经济转型相媲美。;

;
;
;
;
;
;

;与英格兰、苏格兰和威尔士北部和中部地区的迅速衰落相对应是伦敦和东南部的上升。英国的这个角落在 20 世纪 70 年代末就已经是欧洲知识密集型服务业的领跑者，也是世界上最适合起飞的地区之一。因此，自那时以来，英国地区经济不平等的增长速度比富裕和中等收入国家<小>;经合组织;俱乐部中任何其他大型成员的增长速度都要快。伦敦与东南部以及该国其他地区之间的差距现在比德国西部和东部或意大利北部和南部之间的差距还要大。

;

;但还有第二个不太为人所知的部分;英国;的故事。随着中央政府退出其指导经济的角色，它开始将其角色集中在英国政治中。与大多数其他国家不同，经济分权并没有与政治分权结合在一起。

;

;20 世纪 80 年代的美国总统罗纳德·里根 (Ronald Reagan) 将权力从华盛顿特区移至州议会大厦。他的法国总统弗朗索瓦·密特朗从巴黎到其他地区也做了同样的事情。相比之下，在英国，撒切尔夫人废除了可以为其左翼竞争对手提供基础的大城市政府，并大幅削减了地区政策支出。

;

;20 世纪 80 年代的治理集中化使得英国政策制定者难以找到政治能量或政策杠杆来应对日益加剧的地区不平等。过去十年的政治做出了回应：非英格兰国家的分离主义抬头，“不满的地域”（面临相对经济衰退的地方）的规模足以动摇关于<小>;欧盟;成员资格的公投2016 年。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;根据近百次采访，其中包括三位前任我们的新论文“为什么<小>;英国;地区政策没有发挥作用？”与英国首相和六位前财政大臣合作，就该国如何陷入当前的混乱局面达成了广泛共识。< /p>;

;20世纪80年代的集权政治投下了长长的阴影。地方政府也被掏空，并与注重交付的新工党政府争夺合法性。国家在交通和创新方面的支出仍然偏向于东南部的“更安全的赌注”。

;

;由于白厅缺乏向英国地区释放资金和权力的信心，我们反而看到了一系列短暂的区域倡议，每一项都在其落地之前就被连根拔起：20世纪90年代的开发公司； 2000 年代的区域发展机构； 2010 年代的地方经济伙伴关系。我们采访过的所有政策制定者都对这种政策混乱和缺乏一致性表示遗憾。

;

;高层政治家的持续支持和跨党派的支持对于实现持久改革至关重要。它们帮助确保了国家最低工资、英格兰银行的独立性和增加国家医疗服务的资金，这些都在近几十年来从激烈争论转变为广泛政治共识的主题。

;

;这两个因素都已在区域政策方面缺席。自 1979 年撒切尔夫人上任以来，对于支持英格兰地区以及赋予英国其他国家权力所需的措施，首相及其财政大臣的看法从未完全一致。相反，“升级”往往又回到了中央管理的现金储备，由国家公务员分配，并响应政党政治需要而不是经济需要。

;

;好消息是，这可能是改变。自2000年代末以来，从工党领导层开始并由保守党加速，一种新的改革方法悄然改变了英国地方政府：地方政府和中央政府之间的联盟进行交易，通过分散支出和权力来推动地方改革。大曼彻斯特和西米德兰兹郡的强大“都市市长”现在拥有与卡迪夫和爱丁堡的权力下放政府相同的信誉，他们已经通过共识逐步建立了自己的权力基础。

;

;在支出和支出方面仍然存在艰难的决定。税收，以及地方政治无法实现的强制改革。在<小>;英国;——一个人口异常稠密、各地收入差距巨大的国家——权力下放必然是困难的。将征税工作转移给地方政府可能会加剧不平等。但我们的受访者持谨慎乐观的态度，认为该国可能偶然发现了一个行之有效的方案：在英格兰地区和非英格兰国家提供高地位的政治职位，最终为权力下放的良性循环创造了条件。

;

;当各政党为大选做准备时，他们应该留意我们采访过的所有主要政党领导人的结论：现在是发挥政治勇气的时候了，就未来的问题达成跨党派的长期共识。 ;英国;的国家和地区。这将意味着承担风险并尝试不同的治理国家的方式。但如果不做出改变，就意味着过去50年的惨淡记录将继续下去。英国可以做得更好。;■;
